text: [Exhales]
OK. I got it this time.
I got it. (x6)

Hi.
My name is Summer Jackson
and I'm an assistant professor
in the Organizational Behavior Unit
at Harvard Business School.
[Slide reading "What are your research interests?"]
So I study organizational inequality,

and I look at social categories
like race, class, and gender.

But more specifically,
I look at what organizations can do

to try and build diverse, equitable,
and inclusive workplaces.
[Slide reading "Why is this research important?"]
So this research is important

because we spend most of our lives
in organizations, and it's important

that these places are representative
of our communities and our country.

And on an individual level, it's important
that people feel like they are included,

that they can be themselves
and that they belong,

because that's
how we're going to unlock the power

that they can bring
to the workplace every day.
[Slide reading "What excites you most about the future of this research?"]

There
are a lot of things that make me excited

and hopeful about research that's focused
on organizational inequality.

But the main reason that I'm excited
is that organizations

are increasingly interested
in doing something

about being more diverse,
more inclusive, and more equitable.

And importantly, their employees are being
better supported and better resourced

and being given opportunities
to try and transform their organizations.

And I'm excited to be a thought partner
in this research and learn what's working

what isn't, and try to amplify practices
so that organizations and we as a society

can really address
organizational inequality together.
[Slide reading "What item did you bring and how does it best describe you?"]

So I brought this mug,
which is from my time at the U.S.

Department of State,
and it's from the office where I worked,

which is called the U.S. Middle East
Partnership Initiative.

And this mug is important to me
because public service is important to me.

And I feel like if I wasn't studying
organizational inequality
from an academic perspective,

I would still be working
on it out there in the field.
